title: 106_s148
content:
The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress finds that approximately 500 bird species in the United States migrate among countries, with many wintering in Latin America and the Caribbean. These neotropical migratory birds provide valuable benefits to the environment, economy, and recreation. However, their populations are declining due to habitat loss and degradation, putting their long-term survival at risk. The decline in neotropical migratory bird populations is primarily due to habitat loss and degradation, including pollution and contamination. Conservation efforts require the commitment of all countries along their migration routes, and increased coordination can enhance existing initiatives. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, support conservation initiatives in the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean, and foster international cooperation for these initiatives. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

In this Act:
(1) Account.--The term ``Account'' means the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account established by section 9(a).
(2) Conservation.--The term ``conservation'' means methods necessary to ensure the long-term viability of neotropical migratory bird species, including protection, management, research, law enforcement, and community outreach.
(3) Secretary.--The term ``Secretary'' means the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities, including individuals, government agencies, and international organizations. To be considered for financial assistance under this Act, an applicant must submit a project proposal that includes the name of the project leader, project purposes, qualifications of project staff, estimated funds and time needed, and how the project will enhance conservation efforts. The project proposal must include a succinct statement of purposes, qualifications of project staff, estimated funds and time needed, mechanisms for local public participation, consultation with relevant authorities, sensitivity to local resources, and compliance with laws to enhance conservation efforts for neotropical migratory bird species. The project proposal must include consultation with wildlife management authorities, sensitivity to local resources, compliance with laws, promotion of sustainable bird conservation programs, and submission of periodic progress reports to the Secretary. The project proposal must include consultation with wildlife management authorities, sensitivity to local resources, compliance with laws, promotion of sustainable bird conservation programs, and submission of periodic progress reports to the Secretary. Recipients of assistance must submit periodic reports for project evaluation. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25 percent, and the non-Federal share must not come from any Federal grant program, with cash payment required for projects in the United States. The non-Federal share for projects in the United States must be paid in cash, while for projects in foreign countries, it can be paid in cash or in kind. The Secretary's duties under the Act include developing guidelines for project proposals, encouraging submissions from wildlife management authorities, selecting proposals that meet requirements and address conservation needs, and implementing the Act as intended. Cooperation is also emphasized. The Secretary shall support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, exchanging information, entering agreements, and coordinating activities with existing conservation projects. An advisory group may be convened to assist in carrying out the Act. The Secretary may convene an advisory group consisting of individuals representing organizations involved in neotropical migratory bird conservation. The advisory group will hold public meetings and allow interested persons to present statements on agenda items. The advisory group meetings must be open to the public and provide an opportunity for interested persons to present statements. The Secretary must give timely notice of each meeting and keep minutes available to the public. The group is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary must report to Congress by October 1, 2002, on the program's results and effectiveness under this Act, with recommendations for improvement and whether the program should continue. Additionally, there is a Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account established. Establishment of the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury, funded by donations and appropriations. The Secretary can use the funds for program implementation without further appropriation, with a limit of 3% or $80,000 for administrative expenses. The Secretary can use funds from the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account for program implementation without further appropriation. Up to 3% or $80,000 can be used for administrative expenses. Donations can also be accepted and used for carrying out the Act. Authorization of appropriations for the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account is set at $5,000,000 annually from 2001 to 2005, with a requirement that at least 75 percent of the funds be used for projects outside the United States.
